reports.reportTitle: The Federal Reserve has lowered rates three times in the second half of 2019, primarily because numerous inflation measures are running below the central bank's stated goal of 2.0%. For example, the widely-followed Consumer Price Index is up at a 1.8% rate over the past year, while the core CPI (ex Food and Energy) is up 2.3%. The rate of the Fed's favorite measure, the Personal Consumption Expenditure Consumer Price Index ex Food and Energy, is up 1.8%, while the overall market-based Personal Consumption Expenditure Consumer Price Index has risen 1.4%.  Despite a low unemployment rate, wage growth is at only 3.0%.  Deeper in the pipeline, we see deflation. The Intermediate Producer Price Index for Unprocessed Goods is down 12.3% over the past year, and the Intermediate Producer Price Index for Processed Goods is down 3.7%.  Looking to the future, bond investors are not anticipating a pick-up in inflation any time soon. The implied long-term inflation rate as expressed in the 10-year TIPS bonds is 1.66%.  Little wonder that the 2-year T-note yield is near 1.63% and the 10-year yield is near 1.85%

reports.headHtml: Analyst Report: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd
reports.reportTitle: Alibaba provides Chinese and international e-commerce platforms, logistics, and ancillary services. The company operates in four segments: Core Commerce; Cloud Computing; Digital Media & Entertainment; and Innovation Initiatives. Key marketplaces include Taobao, a consumer marketplace; Tmall, a third-party platform for brands and retailers; Juhuasuan, a platform for 'flash' sales; and Alibaba.com and 1688.com, which are online wholesale marketplaces. Additional platforms include Alitrip (online travel booking), Alipay (online payments), Lazada (online commerce in Southeast Asia), and multiple others.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: BABA, IBM, HD, LGF/A
reports.reportTitle: The stock market closed a rough and wild week on August 16 with a rally that failed to undo fully some earlier damage. The DJIA fell about 400 points in the week, or by 1.5%, while the S&P 500 declined by 40 points, or about 1%. Although early August featured fierce selling in leadership groups such as Technology, the Nasdaq relatively outperformed last week, declining about 0.8%.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: CMS, TGNA, GIS, RL, WYNN, CFX, BABA
reports.reportTitle: The major indices are moving upwards at midday on Wednesday after starting the day lower. Disney made headlines yesterday after it agreed to acquire the final 33% of Hulu from its broadcast TV competitor, Comcast. The deal, valued at $5.8 billion, would give Disney complete control of the streaming service within the next five years. Industries doing well today include Interactive Media & Services, Beverages, and Personal Products. Industries showing weakness include Auto Components, Aerospace & Defense, and Banks. The VIX is up 0.67 to 18.73 after the previous close of 18.06. The Dow rose 0.5%, the S&P 0.6%, and the Nasdaq 1.0%. Crude oil fell slightly to $61.50 per barrel, while gold traded near $1298 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: FLEX, NOC, PG, RTN, UPS, X, FB, BABA
reports.reportTitle: Stocks moved mostly higher on Thursday afternoon as investors weighed another round of earnings reports and new employment and housing market data. The Commerce Department, catching up after the government shutdown, said that new home sales jumped a strong 16.9% to a seasonally adjusted 657,000 in November. On the employment front, the Labor Department reported that first-time unemployment claims rose by 53,000 to 253,000 for the week ended January 26, likely reflecting the impact of the shutdown. The Reuters consensus had projected a smaller increase to 215,000. The data came ahead of the government's January employment report on Friday morning. The current consensus calls for an increase of 165,000 jobs, down from 312,000 in December. The Dow fell 0.06%, the S&P rose 0.86%, and the Nasdaq rose 1.17%. Crude oil fell slightly to $54 per barrel, while gold rose $10 to $1,325 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: APA, EMR, INCY, PEG, STX, SYMC, BABA
reports.reportTitle: Although markets have shown some resiliency in November, a bruising October left its mark. On the S&P 500, October 2018 was down 6.9%, representing the worst month since a 7.2% decline in September 2011. And you have to go all the way back to 2008 to find a worse October; in that year, the index plunged 12.4% in October, the worst single month amid a 38.5% full-year decline.
